Html:
I'd like to record audio and immediately draw the waveform of the recorded audio and.... meanwhile being able to play (scrub actually) in the audio that was recorded.

What will probably make it complex is that I want to play in the audiofile that is still being recorded.

Although I'm a vb.net programmer, I can read C# quite well. Would anyone have examples that would proof the concept/possibility of these principles?

Probably the easiest solution is to buffer recorded audio into memory using something similar to BufferedWaveProvider. You can play from a WAV file you are writing to, but it is fairly tricky to get right.

Hi Mark,

thanks for your answer. You responded to our message on the forum, but I also sent you a personal email.

The forum is not the place to discuss possible payment etc. so that's why I mailed you.

The message that I mean is underneath here. If possible, could you reply to me? thanks!

regards,

Martijn

------

Hi Mark,

I've been meaning to mail you for a while.

My company develops audio related products on a small scale. I've been following the Naudio developments for a while now.

I'll cut to the point.

We need to develop a product that can record audio and meanwhile play (scrub rather) thru the same file. Ideally you would be able to scrub right upto the current recording marker.

The biggest challenge lies in reading the data that is still being written in. We also need the waveform of the recorded audio to be drawn up immediately, so you can visualize where you want to scrub. But that's not really the hard part.

We need to select the most suitable audio library for it and we are currently doing just that.

We develop a lot of applications and our preferred language is VB.net.

I realize Naudio is open source, nevertheless I would like to ask you these questions:

-Would the above, to your opinion, be achievable?

-If yes, would you or someone else be able to supply us with a code example, as a proof of concept, preferably in VB.net

-if yes too, what would you like to see in return? Our budgets are limited, but a reasonable payment for such a thing should be possible I think.

Hope to hear soon,

best regards,

Martijn
